note.p: Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers, and Deuteronomy begin with a new column, four lines being left blank at the end of the preceding column. Every column begins with a new verse, and the initial letter is usually ו.
The Song Ha᾿azinu in Deuteronomy 32 written in 67 lines, preceded by six lines of text, with usual initial word, and one blank line. Verses 44-47 are written in five lines.
The second דרש in Lev. 10:16 is written at the beginning of the line, and the "puncta extraordinaria" are placed on the ten words prescribed by the masorah.
The Song of Moses, Exodus 15, and the five lines of text preceding and following it, are written in accordance with the rule.

condition.p: Edge damage, surface abrasion, tears, and losses. Text partly illegible.
Some old patches with red rot.
Dark, hard or stretchy edges from manufacture.
Pleats and folds occasionally obscure text.
Some parts very wormed at edges and joins.

layout.p: Made up of a number of fragments pieced together.
226 columns in total, one to seven columns per membrane.
No tagin, except for three tagin on שעטנזגץ in Ex. 14:28-20:21. The letter ח is arched in some of the fragments.
Majuscular and minuscular letter in accordance with the rules.
Special shape of the letter פ occurs frequently, inverted נ is placed before and after Num. 10:35-36.
The "puncta extraordinaria" placed on the words fixed by masorah.

handDesc.summary: Oriental square script of the 15th century.

recordHist.source: Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.
